qas.question: What is necessary to stabilize the low oxidation state of zinc(l) compounds?
What core do most zinc(l) compounds contain?
What confirms the dimeric structure of the compound?
When a solution of metallic zinc is cooled in molten ZnCl2, what is formed?
What is necessary to stabilize the high oxidation state of zinc(l) compounds?
What core do all zinc(l) compounds contain?
What ruins the dimeric structure of the compound?
When a solution of metallic zinc is heated in molten ZnCl2, what is formed?

context: Zinc(I) compounds are rare, and require <a0_0><b4_0>bulky ligands<b4_0/><a0_0/> to stabilize the low oxidation state. Most zinc(I) compounds contain formally the <a1_0><b5_0>[Zn2]2+<b5_0/><a1_0/> core, which is analogous to the [Hg2]2+ dimeric cation present in mercury(I) compounds. The <a2_0><b6_0>diamagnetic nature of the ion<b6_0/><a2_0/> confirms its dimeric structure. The first zinc(I) compound containing the Zn—Zn bond, (η5-C5Me5)2Zn2, is also the first dimetallocene. The [Zn2]2+ ion rapidly disproportionates into zinc metal and zinc(II), and has only been obtained as a <a3_0><b7_0>yellow glass<b7_0/><a3_0/> formed by cooling a solution of metallic zinc in molten ZnCl2.
